arm_group.description: diagnostic whole body MRI, and skeletal imaging following guidelines (whole body radiographic and scintigraphic screening)

brief_summary.textblock:
The diagnosis of abuse in children relies heavily on the presence of skeletal and
      extraskeletal injuries. However, some lesions are not seen by initial skeletal survey.  And
      the investigators have to complete the skeletal survey with either bone-scan or CT scan or
      whole-body MRI. whole-body MRI has proved its worth in the pediatric population for the
      evaluation of skeletal and extraskeletal lesions in children with cancer or infectious
      diseases. Thus, whole-body MRI would allowed to have total picture of children without
      ionising radiation exposure.

clinical_study.brief_title: Utility of Whole-body MRI in the Detection of Traumatic Injuries of Undetermined Origin in Children

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Infant hospitalised for sub-dural hematoma or skeletal injuries due to non accidental
             traumatism or skin lesions or abdominal injuries of undetermined origin

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Sub-dural hematoma of accidental origin or skeletal injuries of accidental

          -  Origin or known origin of lesions.

          -  Subject already included in the study

intervention.description: diagnostic whole body MRI, both STIR and diffusion weighted

clinical_study.official_title: Utility of Whole-body MRI (STIR and Diffusion Weighted) in the Detection of Traumatic Injuries of Undetermined Origin in Children

oversight_info.authority: France: Afssaps - Agence française de sécurité sanitaire des produits de santé (Saint-Denis)
